So Ι believe: Chrysogonus is so delighted with their literary ability and town-bred refinement that he desires these men to associate with his own effeminate slaves equipped with all the charms of luxury and skill, the pick of many a well-trained household—these men who are little more than labourerS, trained by a country-bred master of a household at Ameria.

121. This is not so, you may be certain, gentlemen: it is not probable that Chrysogonus took a fancy to their literary ability and culture, it is not probable that he knew their energy and loyalty in the business of his household: there is something that is hidden, something that shines forth to view the more clearly, the more eagerly they smother and conceal it.

122. What is it then? Is it in order to hide his own guilt that Chrysogonus refuses to allow them to be examined‘? By no means, gentlemen: all things are not expedient for all men. In Chrysogonus' case, so far as Ι am concerned, I have no suspicion of that sort3 and this is not the first time that it has occurred to me to make this statement.
